description: Borrowed from French cachet, first appearing in Scottish English, from 1630.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A seal, as of a letter.
(figurative) A special characteristic or quality; prestige, especially via association.
examples: Synonyms: charm, je ne sais quoi, magic touch, oomph, zing
I remember when this diner was a quiet hangout, but lately it seems to be losing its cachet.

entries.meaning: (philately) A commemorative stamped design or inscription on an envelope, other than a cancellation or pre-printed postage.
A sealed envelope containing an item whose price is being negotiated.
examples: The most romantic rite of bargaining is the cachet; even its name suggests a thrilling secrecy. The cachet is used when a broker negotiates the sale of a diamond.

entries.meaning: (medicine) A capsule containing a pharmaceutical preparation.
examples: In order to facilitate taking by the patient, powders are often ordered to be dispensed in cachets.

entries.meaning: A hidden location from which one can observe birds while remaining unseen.
examples: On my way back to my cachet I met another party of reed-buntings, one of which I bagged; then I sat in my hiding-place for an hour, waiting for geese that never came within range.

verbs.description: cachet (third-person singular simple present cachets, present participle cacheting, simple past and past participle cacheted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, philately) To mark (an envelope) with a commemorative stamped design or inscription.
